The intrigue unfolds through interviews with the characters closest to Vincent and through dramatic reconstructions of the events leading up to his death.', 'Starring', 'Saoirse Ronan (Brooklyn)', 'Saoirse', 'Ronan', '(', 'Brooklyn', ')', 'Aidan Turner (The Hobbit)', 'Aidan Turner', '(', 'The Hobbit', ')', 'Helen McCrory (Skyfall)', 'Helen', 'McCrory', '(', 'Skyfall', ')', 'Douglas Booth (Pride and Prejudice and Zombies)', 'Douglas', 'Booth', '(', 'Pride and Prejudice and Zombies', ')', "Chris O'Dowd (Bridesmaids, Get Shorty)", "Chris O'Dowd", '(', 'Bridesmaids', ',', 'Get', 'Shorty', ')', 'Review', '"…the filmmakers transform famous works of modern art into a hypnotic and beguiling cartoon." --A. O. Scott, The New York Times"Animated Feature Loving Vincent Takes Hand-Crafting to New Heights" --Karen Idelson, Variety"…a fitting, miraculous tribute to its subject." --Joe McGovern, Entertainment Weekly']
Average Rating: 4.7
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Animation, Anime & Manga', 'Format': 'NTSC, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Jerome Flynn, Douglas Booth, Hugh Welchman, Saoirse Ronan, Dorota Kobiela, Aidan Turner, Helen McCrory, Chris O DowdJerome Flynn, Douglas Booth, Hugh Welchman, Saoirse Ronan, Dorota Kobiela, Aidan Turner, Helen McCrory, Chris O Dowd  See more', 'Language': 'English', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 35 minutes', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG-13 (Parents Strongly Cautioned)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': 'GDDE5651DVD DVD', 'Director': 'Dorota Kobiela, Hugh Welchman', 'Media Format': 'NTSC, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 35 minutes', 'Release date': 'February 1, 2019', 'Actors': 'Saoirse Ronan, Aidan Turner, Helen McCrory, Douglas Booth, Chris O Dowd', 'Dubbed': 'English', 'Studio': 'Good Deed Entertainment', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: Beautiful and tender. I've heard the story of Vincent Van Gogh's life several times before, but this was the first time it really hit me in the heart. This movie is a masterpiece, the art of film at its finest. I plan to watch it again. I can count on one hand the number of movies I've said that about, and I've seen a lot!
Review Title: Now I think I know...
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Ken Kwapis'], 'Producers': ['Robert Redford', 'Bill Holderman', 'Chip Diggins', 'Jeremiah Samuels', 'Jake Eberts'], 'Starring': ['Robert Redford', 'Nick Nolte', 'Emma Thompson'], 'Studio': ['Broad Green Pictures']}
Not a patch on the book. Bryson's wit replaced with vulgarity. Completely lacking in the true challenge of the experience. Ending anticlimactic. Insipid. I guess the money was too tempting. Only redeeming feature of this film was the acting.
Disappointment.
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['Français'], 'Subtitles': ['English'], 'Directors': ['Anne Fontaine'], 'Producers': ['Eric Altmayer', 'Nicolas Altmayer'], 'Starring': ['Lou de Laage', 'Agata Buzek', 'Agata Kulesza'], 'Studio': ['Music Box Films']}
A profound movie about the atrocities of war. Beautifully crafted, visually stunning, bleak and stark, but with moments of utter tenderness, I found it as heartwarming and it was painful. The atrocities themselves were not depicted, and this absence was the work of genius that left room for an examination of the depths and heights humanity can reach. There is hope to be found, and much love, and for some, faith. I'm so glad I found out about this film. I loved it. So very thought provoking.
Profound movie, refreshing in its simplicity.
{'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Hope Dickson Leach'], 'Producers': ['Rachel Robey'], 'Starring': ['Ellie Kendrick', 'David Troughton', 'Jack Holden'], 'Studio': ['Monterey Media']}
A massive festival of human and animal misery and nothing else. Miserable people, miserable circumstances, miserable setting. Thoroughly depressing and unconvincing. Overacted, overwritten. Truly wretched. A study in how people do not behave in reality, no matter how dire the circumstances.
One Dimensional.
A Street Cat Named Bob
Drama, Kids, Cheerful, Emotional
['Based on the international bestselling book. The true, feel-good story of how James Bowen, a busker and recovering drug addict, had his life transformed when he met a stray ginger cat.']
{'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Roger Spottiswoode'], 'Producers': ['Adam Rolston'], 'Starring': ['Luke Treadaway', 'Ruta Gedmintas', 'Joanne Froggatt']}
This was a sweet film handled very well. Full of hope and love but not overly sugar coating the grit and dangers of drugs and homelessness, it shows how the companionship of a remarkable animal can sometimes be the one thing that pulls people through really tough times. There were some very compassionate and loving humans involved too. Really glad I watched it. A unique story that made such a change from the doom and gloom of so much of what passes as entertainment. This would appeal to a wide age range I believe, and obviously a broad audience. I'm so happy for the success of all involved.
Uplifting Power of Animals
{'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['John Stephenson'], 'Producers': ['Steve Christian', 'Alice Dawson', 'Ivan Dunleavy', 'Huw Penallt Jones', 'Hannah Leader', 'Candace Lee', 'Brian Lockhart', 'Christopher Morrow', 'Tom Newman'], 'Starring': ['Hans Matheson', 'Samantha Barks', 'Susan Boyle'], 'Studio': ['Group 1200 Media']}
Just a sweet Christmas film with a religious theme that's uplifting more than annoying. I allowed myself to be swept into it, and enjoyed every moment of its sentimentality. Very beautiful scenery. British acting well done. Susan Boyle! If only it could be true...
Unapologetically Sweet

profile:
The user maintains a strong preference for high-quality narratives deeply rooted in literary sources, valuing authenticity and emotional depth in storytelling. They critically assess adaptations that deviate from the original material, particularly in tone and complexity, and show a clear aversion to excessive vulgarity, favoring sophisticated humor. Recent interactions highlight an appreciation for profound and thought-provoking films that balance stark themes with moments of tenderness while emphasizing the importance of realistic human behavior in challenging circumstances. 

A notable shift in their preferences is evidenced by a newfound sensitivity to character depth and authenticity, especially in emotionally driven narratives. They have increasingly embraced sentimentality and hope, as indicated by their appreciation for uplifting films, particularly those with rich visual storytelling and meaningful companionship. 

The user seeks media that emphasizes literary fidelity, emotional resonance, and quality performances. They cherish narratives that provide a nuanced exploration of humanity amidst life's complexities, showcasing genuine connections even within darker themes. Their tastes reflect a blend of critical engagement with serious subject matter and a growing inclination towards lighthearted, uplifting narratives that foster emotional connection and depth.
